The 5 Most Common Mistakes that Cause Cervical Pain and How to Avoid Them

Introduction

Cervical pain is one of the most common ailments today, especially due to excessive screen use and daily stress. This condition can affect your quality of life and interfere with daily activities. Below, we analyze the five most common mistakes that cause cervical pain and how to prevent them to maintain an optimal neck health.

1. Poor Posture in Front of Screens

Incorrect posture in front of the computer or mobile device can cause strain on the neck and shoulder muscles. This issue, known as “tech neck”, is becoming more and more common.

How to avoid it?

  • Adjust the screen to eye level to reduce neck flexion.
  • Make sure your back is supported and your feet are flat on the ground.
  • Take active breaks every 30-40 minutes to stretch and mobilize your neck.

2. Inadequate Pillow and Incorrect Sleeping Postures

Using an inadequate pillow can cause tension and stiffness upon waking.

How to avoid it?

  • Use an ergonomic pillow that keeps your head aligned with your spine.
  • Avoid sleeping on your stomach, as it forces neck twisting.
  • If you sleep on your side, make sure the pillow fills the space between your head and shoulder.

3. Stress and Accumulated Tension

Emotional stress is one of the main causes of muscle tension, especially in the cervical area.

How to avoid it?

  • Include relaxation techniques like deep breathing and meditation.
  • Exercise regularly to reduce stress.
  • Consider physiotherapy sessions to release accumulated tension.

4. Sudden Movements or Overload

Poor technique when lifting weights can overload the cervical muscles and cause injuries.

How to avoid it?

  • Warm up before exercising.
  • Use proper techniques for lifting objects.
  • If you practice sports, follow a professional's recommendations.

5. Lack of Exercise for the Neck and Shoulders

A weak musculature in the cervical area increases the risk of pain.

How to avoid it?

  • Include specific exercises to strengthen the neck and shoulders.
  • Do regular stretches to improve flexibility.
  • Consult a physiotherapist for a personalized exercise plan.

Conclusion

Cervical pain can be avoided by correcting habits such as posture, rest, and strengthening. If you experience recurring discomfort, it is advisable to consult a specialized physiotherapist for proper treatment.
